I received clear feedback that improved my learning

Comments_List: Some additional Bayesian statistics knowledge. I gained a better foundational understanding of how to calculate a posterior distribution. Less afraid of these sorts of simple statistical frameworks now.

I picked up an appreciation of probability and stats from a bayesian framework. The theory, in particular, was a gentle introduction. I have programming background so the R exercises just helped me understand the underlying math. Props to MCMC and Metropolis stuff.
Bayesian. Some other stuff. Maybe I should look at the material so I can do well on the exam.

Statistics
R programming

This class really helped me understand the intersection of probability and statistics; what the fields mean and how they relate. The culmination of the course is to learn how to use an incredibly powerful tool that helps compute statistics, and has been very practical for my research.
conditional probability, bayesian statistics, R simulation, JAGS, Markov chains
Basic knowledge about probability

Lectures were pretty weak. He spends a bit too much time talking about unimportant stuff and explaining simple details of R programming that one could learn during the homeworks, and less time than would be ideal focused on the actual statistics and theory.

The class itself was clearly structured. Lectures were well prepared. The prof. responded to inquiry readily, eagerly, and quickly. Grades were returned in a timely manner and the prof was more fair when it came to deadlines and grades. 

The topics covered were pretty good, but the course felt rushed at the end where I feel like I missed some key insights that would have been great to walk away with.
Strength: good structure, very helpful in terms of both theory and programming

Strengths: Joe Chang is an incredibly insightful and caring professor. His examples are useful for building up intuition around the concepts of the class, and he has excellent answers to questions when you meet.

strength: Practical problem sets, great resources, great online support as well
weaknesses: could be a lot of work for someone not having done math in a while

I think the problem sets were extremely hard and lengthy, which ruined much of the learning value and joy from this course. 

I would suggest using less tricky notation (just changing superscripts or subscripts), expecting wild mental leaps we wouldn't know without the TAs and examples in Psets where we don't have to learn new course material whilst we are doing the PSet, but first try to even apply *exactly* what we learnt in class.
It is easy to make students understand

The course was well planned and had a satisfactory level of challenge. I liked the curriculum and the lectures.

To improve, I would suggest less formulaic midterms and final. These tests were so similar to the practice tests (taken from prior year exams) that they seemed to test how carefully those sample tests had been studied rather than actual understanding of course material. (For example, some questions would be very difficult to solve in the time allotted using just course knowledge, but they were near copies of sample questions.)
Yes, because it seems like the best introduction to the key pieces of stats needed for scientific work that Yale currently offers.
I would recommend this course to many people, but only if they had some fluency in math to start with. My calc background is lacking, which made the first half of the course rather cumbersome.
Yes.
Yes. It is helpful for me to understand the theory better by doing simulation. I have taken similar courses in probability and this is the best one.

Yes! If you are interested in a grounding in concepts of Bayesian statistics (different from Frequentist statistics, we did not talk much about p-values or t-tests, etc. other than to compare them with Bayesian concepts), then this is an excellent introductory class. The math is fun, the p-sets are challenging (be prepared to go to office hour(s) and spend several hours of time a week, and everything in the class comes together at the end to make for a very satisfying conclusion through MCMC and statistical inference.
Yes. Because it's a different type of probability and statistics.
Yes, if you are into mathematical notation and want to understand statistics and probability theory
Yes. Good for beginners
For students who have taken calculus and have had some previous exposure to statistics and probability concepts, this course seems to be good preparation for more advanced topics.
